lines.text:
[On the phone]
This is Prosecutor von Wenk! Dr. Mabuse, I ask you to offer no resistance against the state authorities and turn yourself in.
I feel like a state within a state with which I have always been at war! If you want me, come and get me!
We are prepared to move against you using the harshest measures. Give up your senseless resistance!
I have learned of something that until recently I didn't believe, that there still apparently exists in this world something more valuable and more deeply moving than the strongest thrill. Love , , ,
There is no love. There is only desire! There is no happiness. There is only the will to power!
Those are Chinese glasses.
Yes, from TSI-NAN-FU-!
Take some cocaine, you wimp!

[First lines]
You're hopped up on cocaine again, Spoerri!
I can't take this any longer, this pace of 200 km an hour! It's modern-day cannibalism!
00. Guests welcome. The Union of Psychoanalytic Research.

[after a night of cards playing "Mr. Balling"- the mind-controlling Dr. Mabuse in disguise]
I've lost again. Until tomorrow afternoon, you'll have to make do with 20,000 marks and a promissory note of 150,000 marks.
I played and I lost. But to whom exactly?
To your friend!
Friend? What do you mean? It's the first time I've seen the man. Who brought him into the club?
I think you've had too much to drink, Hull! First, with your bad luck you call "go bank" and then you claim not to know the very man that you yourself invited into the club!
If you can't find your man, you just might find your woman!

For approximately six weeks, complaints of predatory gamblers have been coming into the authorities. It's been impossible to prove foul play in any of these cases. However, their luck in the game is so improbable, that something surely is amiss. It's always someone different. Sometimes it's a young gentleman, at other times a respectable shopkeeper. Today it's a blond American, tomorrow a dark-haired Russian. It is always someone different.
Am I really nothing more than an instrument to you?
What kind of dangerous acquaintances have you been making recently?
What's a woman like yourself doing in such a place, amongst pushers, gamblers and call girls?
We have weary hearts, Mr. von Wenk. We need thrills of a very special nature in order to endure this life.
I prefer to observe the passions that gambling arouses, reflected in the mirror of others, without coming into close contact with such players themselves.
Will you accept this? It costs $50,000 at Tiffany's in New York. Against the bank.
Even the loveliest of women is quite capable of keeping intriguing secrets.
I need in life a strong breath of extraordinary thrills and adventures; but, I fear such things have become extinct.
This man, the enemy I pursue, I do not know who he is. I only know that he exists.
Beware of von Wenk!
You gamble with money, with people and with fate and most horrifying of all, with your own self.

[Password]
Pineapple.
Cocaine or cards?
Cards.
You goddamned snooping dog!
About to make a fuss, you swine? What am I paying you for, if at the first opportunity you flounder like schoolgirls?
You do seem to possess the "open sesame" to every secret door, Mr. Prosecutor.
"All that pleases is allowed."
Let the games begin!
The smart thing is to give in.

I'm afraid there's absolutely nothing in this world that can hold my interest in the long run. Everything that can be observed from a car, from a theater box or from the window, is part repulsive, part uninteresting, and, at least, boring.
Gambling with people and with the fates of people.
Where's Wenk?
Boys, things are getting nasty.
I'll give you one more week for Wenk, so you can get the job done right, but not one minute longer.
The woman. That woman!
Have you no shame?
The prosecutor is finally at the end of his rope. And now he hopes to get help from me. From me, a woman who's just as wretched and forsaken as a stray dog.
Nobody knows who he really is. He exist! He lives! He towers over the city. He is damnation and heavenly bliss. He is the greatest man alive. And he loved me.
What do you make of Expressionism, Doctor?
Now the world shall learn who I am! I, Mabuse! I will become a giant, a titan who scatters the gods and the laws into a swirl like withered leaves!
My wife has left me. She's probably gone back to her mother.
Please get me Count Told. The countess is not at her mother's.
The man for whose sake you are being held has tossed you out like fruit that's been squeezed dry.

[Posing as Sandor Weltmann]
Ladies and Gentlemen, I would now like to demonstrate for you one of the most typical cases of mass suggestion, which is not unlike the tricks of the Indian Fakirs which arise from it.
Dr. Mabuse, the doctor, the gambler, the outlaw!
We can't go out. The police have the house surrounded!
Then it's war!

[Repeated line]
TSI-NAN-FU-!
Where's Mabuse?
